title: 113_hr4287
content: The "Independent Innovator and Repurposing Act" may extend the patent term for the method of using biological products. The "Extension for Regulatory Delay" allows a 5-year extension of a patent for using a biological product if certain conditions are met, including submitting an application to the Director with specific information about the product and patent. To apply for a patent extension under this section, the owner or agent must submit an application to the Director with details about the biological product, the patent, and proof of independent innovation or ownership by a qualified small business. Additionally, evidence of filing for commercial marketing of the product and a minimum of 10 years passing since the patent issuance are required. To apply for a patent extension, the owner or agent must submit an application with details about the biological product, the patent, evidence of filing for commercial marketing, and a minimum of 10 years passing since the patent issuance. The extension determination is based on the activities undertaken by the owner or agent during this period. The owner or agent must submit an application for a patent extension based on activities related to the biological product. The Director will determine eligibility and issue a 5-year extension certificate if requirements are met. An interim extension may be granted if the patent term would expire before a decision is made. The Director may grant an interim extension of up to one year for a patent if an application for extension is pending and the patent term would expire before a decision is made. Definitions include "biological product" and "Director" as per the Public Health Service Act. The Director, as defined by the Under Secretary of Commerce for Intellectual Property and Director of the US Patent and Trademark Office, may grant an interim extension for a patent. An "independent innovator" is someone who obtains a method of use patent for a biological product and is not affiliated with the holder of a marketing application approved under the Public Health Service Act. A "qualified small business" is also defined. The term "affiliated" includes relationships of employment, control, or common ownership, whether direct or indirect. A "qualified small business" is defined as an entity with fewer than 500 employees, not affiliated with the holder of a marketing application for a biological product. This section takes effect upon the enactment of the Act and applies to unexpired patents issued before or after that date.
